Calculate Glasgow-Blatchford Bleeding Score (GBS) by summing the results of the following rules:
    Hemoglobin level (g/dL): Enter value (norm: 12-17 g/dL)
    BUN level (mg/dL): Enter value (norm: 8-20 mg/dL)
    Initial systolic blood pressure (mm Hg): Enter value (norm: 100-120 mm Hg)
    Sex: Female = +1 point, Male = 0 points
    Heart rate ≥100: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Melena present: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Recent syncope: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Hepatic disease history: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Cardiac failure present: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points

A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling of his right leg for the past 2 days. Three days ago he collapsed on his leg after tripping on a rug. It was a hard fall and left him with bruising of his leg. Since then the pain and swelling of his leg have been gradually increasing. Past medical history is noncontributory. He lives a rather sedentary life and smokes two packs of cigarettes per day. The vital signs include heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 15/min, temperature 37.8°C (100.1°F), and blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, his right leg is visibly swollen up to the mid-calf with pitting edema and moderate erythema. Peripheral pulses in the right leg are weak and the leg is tender. Manipulation of the right leg is negative for Homan’s sign.

What is the patient’s score of Wells' criteria for Pulmonary Embolism?

Calculate Wells' Criteria for Pulmonary Embolism by summing the results of the following rules:
    Clinical signs and symptoms of DVT: No = 0 points, Yes = +3 points
    PE is #1 diagnosis OR equally likely: No = 0 points, Yes = +3 points
    Heart rate > 100: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Immobilization at least 3 days OR surgery in the previous 4 weeks: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Previous, objectively diagnosed PE or DVT: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Hemoptysis: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Malignancy with treatment within 6 months or palliative: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 22-year-old female presents to the hospital with fatigue and recent headaches. She has a documented history of GERD, a kidney transplant, hypertension, evident with several recorded high blood pressure readings in the clinic. Moreover, she suffered a transient ischemic attack of her brain last year. She was solemn when she shared that she tends to drink more than moderately, admitting to a weekly average of 12 alcoholic beverages. In her medical history, there are suggestive signs of hepatic cirrhosis and confirmed renal disease. She denies using any medication known to exacerbate bleeding such as NSAIDs, anticoagulants or antiplatelet agents. Furthermore, there is no clear history of a major bleeding episode or any known coagulation disorders that predispose her to bleeding. The blood investigations, including coagulation studies, show a stable international normalized ratio (INR), and hemoglobin levels within range. The plan is to continue monitoring her closely and to adjust her therapies as needed based on the comprehensive assessment of her case.

What is the patient's HAS-BLED score?

Calculate HAS-BLED Score for Major Bleeding Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Hypertension (Uncontrolled, >160 mmHg systolic): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Renal disease (Dialysis, transplant, Cr >2.26 mg/dL or >200 µmol/L): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Liver disease (Cirrhosis or bilirubin >2x normal with AST/ALT/AP >3x normal): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Stroke history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Prior major bleeding or predisposition to bleeding: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Labile INR (Unstable/high INRs, time in therapeutic range <60%): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Age >65: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Medication usage predisposing to bleeding (Aspirin, clopidogrel, NSAIDs): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Alcohol use (≥8 drinks/week): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 63-year-old male with recently diagnosed cirrhosis secondary to NAFLD came for a follow-up consultation. During the appointment, he exhibited confusion, asterixis, and slurred speech. Laboratory evaluations were remarkable with an increased INR value at 1.8. Liver function tests showed a total bilirubin count of 1.9 mg/dL and an albumin level of 3.1 g/dL demonstrating compromised liver function. Additional lab tests showed a glucose level at 130 mg/dL, though hemoglobin A1c was within acceptable bounds which indicate fairly well-controlled DM II. The patient was advised to maintain dietary restrictions and adhere to prescribed therapeutic management. Family intervention was also suggested considering his cognitive impairment. He was reassured that they would initiate steps to manage his encephalopathy right away.

    Albumin: >3.5 g/dL (>35 g/L) = +1 point, 2.8-3.5 g/dL (28-35 g/L) = +2 points, <2.8 g/dL (<28 g/L) = +3 points
    INR: <1.7 = +1 point, 1.7-2.3 = +2 points, >2.3 = +3 points
    Ascites: Absent = +1 point, Slight = +2 points, Moderate = +3 points
    Encephalopathy: No Encephalopathy = +1 point, Grade 1-2 = +2 points, Grade 3-4 = +3 points

The patient is a male in his mid-seventies, known to have chronic liver disease. Although a bit anxious, his heart rate was fairly on the high side with a reading of 94 beats per minute, while his systolic blood pressure was measured at 112 mm Hg. He mentions not having suffered any recent episodes of fainting. Laboratory tests showed a Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) level at 26 mg/dL, while his hemoglobin stood healthy at 14.2 g/dL. His clinical presentation, inclusive of past medical history, despite the absence of any alarming symptoms prompts the need for further evaluation given the increased BUN levels.

A 71-year-old male presented to the emergency room with worsening shortness of breath and was admitted to the ICU. His medical history includes mild hepatic and renal impairments which are continuously monitored. Recent laboratory reports revealed a slight increase in creatinine levels of 1.2 mg/dL and bilirubin of 2.2 mg/dL. A Glasgow Coma Scale of 12 indicated slight cognitive impairment. His blood pressure was tightly controlled with readings around 130/85 mm Hg. With agitated breathing patterns, he was started on managed mechanical ventilation to better control his respiratory distress. After receiving oxygen therapy, his fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂) became stabilized at 55 %, this resulted in a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) of 70 mm Hg. Multiple vasopressor therapies were initiated; DOPamine ran at 4 mcg/kg/min, DOBUTamine at the same dosage, norEPINEPHrine at the slightly higher rate of 0.08 mcg/kg/min and EPINEPHrine at 0.09 mcg/kg/min. The platelet count in his blood sample was screened to be 170,000/µL. He had fairly normal urine output documented at 800 mL/day.

What is the patient's Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score?

Calculate Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score by summing the results of the following rules:
    PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio (mm Hg): ≥400 = 0 points, 300-399 = +1 point, 200-299 = +2 points, 100-199 (with respiratory support) = +3 points, <100 (with respiratory support) = +4 points
    Platelets (×10³/µL): ≥150 = 0 points, 100-149 = +1 point, 50-99 = +2 points, 20-49 = +3 points, <20 = +4 points
    Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 15 = 0 points, 13-14 = +1 point, 10-12 = +2 points, 6-9 = +3 points, <6 = +4 points
    Bilirubin (mg/dL): <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-5.9 = +2 points, 6.0-11.9 = +3 points, ≥12.0 = +4 points
    Mean arterial pressure (MAP) or administration of vasopressors: No hypotension = 0 points, MAP <70 mmHg = +1 point, Dopamine ≤5 or Dobutamine (any dose) = +2 points, Dopamine >5 or Epinephrine ≤0.1 or norepinephrine ≤0.1 = +3 points, Dopamine >15 or Epinephrine >0.1 or norepinephrine >0.1 = +4 points
    Creatinine (mg/dL) or urine output: <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-3.4 = +2 points, 3.5-4.9 or urine output <500 mL/day = +3 points, ≥5.0 or urine output <200 mL/day = +4 points

A 58 year old female is brought to the emergency department following a high speed head-on motor vehicle collision. Upon extrication from the vehicle, he was found conscious but confused by emergency responders. Vital signs are notable for  heart rate 100 bpm, blood pressure 150/90 mmHg, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F), and O2 sat 95 % on room air. The patient appears anxious and disoriented. He intermittently opens his eyes in response to verbal commands but is unable to provide accurate information about the injury. He localizes painful stimuli. Cranial nerves are intact. Secondary assessment reveals tenderness and swelling over the right forearm and abdominal tenderness to palpation. Further evaluation with head CT, X-rays of the right forearm, and abdominal imaging are ordered.

A 74-year-old woman living independently visits the clinic reporting malaise and weakness. She has a known history of liver disease. She denies any past heart failure or prior strokes. At present, her mental status appears undisturbed. Today's exam measures her body temperature at 99.5 degrees Fahrenheit, and vitals recorded an elevated heart rate at 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and slightly lower blood pressure at 110/75 mm Hg. Results from arterial blood gas reports a pH of 7.42 and a PaO2 at 84 mm Hg, suggesting good oxygen levels. A recent chest X-ray demonstrates presence of pleural effusion.

A 12-year-old girl was referred to the dental department for the assessment of a long-standing nonhealing ulcer on the labial mucosa of the lower lip. The lesion was first observed by the patient 2 years ago; however, the lesion was brought to the notice of the parents 6 months back which prompted them to seek the treatment. The patient had no symptoms otherwise. The size of the ulcer has remained constant over the past 2 years. There was no history of cough, fever, hemoptysis, and weight loss. She did not have any systemic condition, had no history of allergy, and was not on any medications.
She had consulted two dental practitioners in her village and was treated conservatively with the help of topical medications over the past 6 months. The older prescriptions revealed the use of mucopain gel (benzocaine 1.P. 20%), zytee gel (benzalkonium chloride 0.02%, choline salicylate 9%), and candid mouth paint (clotrimazole 1%). However, there was no change (increase or decrease in the size of the ulcer) or improvement in her clinical condition for the past 6 months.
General physical examination revealed that she weighed 33 kg and was 150 cm tall. The calculated body mass index of 14.7 kg/m2 indicated that she was underweight. Vital signs (heart rate – 82 beats/min, respiratory rate – 16 breaths/min, blood pressure – 120/80 mmHg, body temperature – 98.6°F) were within the normal range. Submandibular and submental groups of lymph nodes were examined and they were nonpalpable and nontender.
Oral examination revealed a round nonhealing ulcer on the labial mucosa of the lower lip on the left side measuring 4 cm × 4 cm. The ulcer was grayish-white in color with irregular borders. The edges were thin and undermined with slight induration at the base []. There was no tenderness on palpation. An incisional biopsy was performed under local anesthesia. The microscopy section from the lower lip showed the hyperplastic squamous epithelium, multiple granulomas composed of epithelioid cells and Langhan's giant cells, surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells []. No caseous necrosis was seen in the biopsy sample obtained. A preliminary diagnosis of TB/sarcoidosis was made.
Blood tests revealed a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (18 mm in the 1st h). The serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level was 58.2 U/L. Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) (Quantiferon-TB [QFT]) was positive (3.43 IU/mL). Results of Mantoux test interpreted 48 h after tuberculin injection (10 T.U) revealed erythema of 16 mm and induration of 18 mm. The chest radiograph revealed the absence of foci of infection indicating no pulmonary involvement. Thus, the diagnosis of primary TB was confirmed.
Treatment with anti-tubercular drugs was initiated. The patient was prescribed isoniazid 150 mg, rifampin 300 mg, pyrazinamide 750 mg, and ethambutol 400 mg daily for 2 months. The second phase of the treatment consisted of isoniazid 150 mg and rifampin 300 mg daily for 4 months. Lesion almost resolved within 3 weeks of initiation of the treatment [].

What is the patient’s score of Wells' criteria for Pulmonary Embolism?

Calculate Wells' Criteria for Pulmonary Embolism by summing the results of the following rules:
    Clinical signs and symptoms of DVT: No = 0 points, Yes = +3 points
    PE is #1 diagnosis OR equally likely: No = 0 points, Yes = +3 points
    Heart rate > 100: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Immobilization at least 3 days OR surgery in the previous 4 weeks: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Previous, objectively diagnosed PE or DVT: No = 0 points, Yes = +1.5 points
    Hemoptysis: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Malignancy with treatment within 6 months or palliative: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 56-year-old woman with a significant history of RCA stenosis with prior bare metal stenting, hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, smoking, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation presented to the emergency department with anginal chest pain. Initial work up showed significant elevation of cardiac troponin T with T-wave inversion in the inferior leads. She subsequently underwent cardiac catheterization. Coronary angiography revealed a 90% stenosis of the midportion of RCA with patent stent at distal portion of RCA (Figure , ) and only mild disease in left anterior descending coronary and left circumflex coronary arteries. An everolimus-eluting stent, 2.5 mm × 23 mm, was placed in the stenosis of midportion of RCA. Immediately after these interventions, thrombus developed and occluded SN artery. It originated from the proximal one third portion of RCA. Electrocardiographic monitoring showed junctional escape rhythm without P waves at a heart rate of 30 beats/min, suggesting sinus arrest (Figure ). To prevent severe bradycardia and hypotension, transvenous temporary pacemaker was placed. The patient remained asymptomatic and without hypotension. The clot in the SN artery was identified and thrombectomy was performed. Within five minutes after intervention, Thrombolysis In Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) flow 3 was observed in the SN artery within 5 minutes and the transvenous temporary pacer was removed. Electrocardiogram revealed persistent junctional escape rhythm for 5 days after revascularization, with restoration of sinus rhythm on the sixth day. Heart rate showed a gradual improvement and the patient maintained a stable heart rate at 60 beats per minute. The patient remained hemodynamically stable without further need for temporary pacing. Pre-discharge exercise stress test had shown 50% predicted heart rate at 100 beats per minute, without ST segment change.

What is the patient's CHA2DS2-VASc Score?

A 56-year-old woman with a significant history of RCA stenosis with prior bare metal stenting, hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, smoking, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation presented to the emergency department with anginal chest pain. Initial work up showed significant elevation of cardiac troponin T with T-wave inversion in the inferior leads. She subsequently underwent cardiac catheterization. Coronary angiography revealed a 90% stenosis of the midportion of RCA with patent stent at distal portion of RCA (Figure , ) and only mild disease in left anterior descending coronary and left circumflex coronary arteries. An everolimus-eluting stent, 2.5 mm × 23 mm, was placed in the stenosis of midportion of RCA. Immediately after these interventions, thrombus developed and occluded SN artery. It originated from the proximal one third portion of RCA. Electrocardiographic monitoring showed junctional escape rhythm without P waves at a heart rate of 30 beats/min, suggesting sinus arrest (Figure ). To prevent severe bradycardia and hypotension, transvenous temporary pacemaker was placed. The patient remained asymptomatic and without hypotension. The clot in the SN artery was identified and thrombectomy was performed. Within five minutes after intervention, Thrombolysis In Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) flow 3 was observed in the SN artery within 5 minutes and the transvenous temporary pacer was removed. Electrocardiogram revealed persistent junctional escape rhythm for 5 days after revascularization, with restoration of sinus rhythm on the sixth day. Heart rate showed a gradual improvement and the patient maintained a stable heart rate at 60 beats per minute. The patient remained hemodynamically stable without further need for temporary pacing. Pre-discharge exercise stress test had shown 50% predicted heart rate at 100 beats per minute, without ST segment change.

Calculate CHA2DS2-VASc Score for Atrial Fibrillation Stroke Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age: < 65 years = 0 points, 65-74 years = +1 point, ≥ 75 years = +2 points
    Sex: Female = +1 point, Male = 0 points
    Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Hypertension history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Stroke, Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA), or Thromboembolism history: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Vascular disease history (previous myocardial infarction, peripheral artery disease, or aortic plaque): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Diabetes history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 68-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department after 2 days of difficulty breathing and fever. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and benign prostate hypertrophy. He takes hydrochlorothiazide and tamsulosin.  He also admits to drinking alcohol on the weekends and a half pack a day smoking habit. Upon admission, he is found to have blood pressure of 125/83 mm Hg, pulse of 88/min, a respiratory rate of 28/min, and a temperature of 38.9°C (102°F). On physical exam breath sounds are decreased at the left pulmonary base. A chest x-ray reveals consolidation in the left lower lobe. Additional laboratory tests demonstrate leukocytosis, elevated C-reactive protein, a serum creatinine (Cr) of 8.0 mg/dL, and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 32 mg/dL. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on cefepime and clarithromycin. His dyspnea slowly improves after 48 hours, however, his body temperature remains at 39°C (102.2°F). Recent laboratory tests show reduced C-reactive protein levels, a Cr of 1.8 mg/dL and a BUN of 35 mg/dL. A urinalysis is ordered.

What is the patient's CURB-65 score?

Calculate CURB-65 Score for Pneumonia Severity by summing the results of the following rules:
    Confusion: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    BUN >19 mg/dL (>7 mmol/L urea): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Respiratory Rate ≥30: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Systolic BP <90 mmHg or Diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Age ≥65: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 72-year-old gentleman presents to the clinic for a pre-operative evaluation ahead of an elective hernia repair surgery. His past medical history is significant for stable ischemic heart disease for which he underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention five years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, well controlled with insulin therapy. No known history of any cerebrovascular events is noted in his records. On examination, his vital signs, respiratory rate, and SpO2 levels are within standard norms. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Pulmonary assessment is unremarkable, with no audible crackles, wheezing, or pleural rubs. Peripheral examination did not reveal any ankle edema. His pre-operative serum creatinine level comes back slightly elevated with a reading of 1.4 mg/dL. Given his clinical history and findings, the patient’s operation will continue as planned with routine post-operative monitoring.

What is the patient's Cardiac Risk Index based on the revised Cardiac Risk Index for pre-operative risk rule?

Calculate Revised Cardiac Risk Index for Pre-Operative Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Elevated-risk surgery (intraperitoneal, intrathoracic, or suprainguinal vascular): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of ischemic heart disease (history of myocardial infarction, positive exercise test, current chest pain due to myocardial ischemia, use of nitrate therapy, or ECG with pathological Q waves): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of congestive heart failure (pulmonary edema, bilateral rales or S3 gallop, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest x-ray showing pulmonary vascular redistribution): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of cerebrovascular disease (prior transient ischemic attack or stroke): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative treatment with insulin: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative creatinine >2 mg/dL (176.8 μmol/L): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 57-year-old man who had alcoholic liver disease and chronic hepatitis C-related Child-Pugh class C liver cirrhosis was brought to our emergency department by ambulance, exhibiting fever, short of breath and a localized wound pain over left ankle. The patient presented with dyspnea, lower extremity edema and some wounds over bilateral ankles area for 1 day before admission, but had no other symptoms, including a headache, sore throat, cough, and chest, abdominal, and back pain. He had alcohol and chronic hepatitis C- related liver cirrhosis, and took diuretics in the past 5 years. He drank approximately 60 g of alcohol per day for more than 20 years, but recently had been taking a bit more than usual.
His laboratory data 2 weeks before admission were 6.5 mg/ dl of total bilirubin, 2.1 g/dl of albumin, and 1.73 of international normalized ratio. In addition, he had moderate ascites, which was medically controlled. These findings were indicative of Child- Pugh class C liver cirrhosis. On arrival, he appeared to be in disturbance and distress that was classified as 13 (E3V4M6) on the Glasgow Coma Scale. His vital signs were 132/106 mmHg of blood pressure, 125 beats/minute of pulse rate, 24 breaths/minute of respiratory rate, and 38.4 °C of body temperature. Auscultation of the lung and heart revealed coarse breath sounds and rapid irregular heartbeats. His abdomen was soft and swollen. Two wounds with redness and swelling (measures 0.5 × 0.5 cm, left ankle; measures 1 × 1 cm, right ankle) were found on his lower extremities ( and ). Chest X-ray indicated a lower lobe infiltration and a mild blunting of C-P angle in the right side (). ECG showed atrial fibrillation.
Laboratory findings also included 8,990/ml of white blood cell count with 94% neutrophils and 3% lymphocytes, 11.1 g/dl of hemoglobin level, 104,000/ml of platelet count, 23 mg/dl of blood urea nitrogen, 1.42 mg/dl of creatinine, 121 mmol/L of sodium, and 4.6 mmol/L of potassium. Ascitic fluid analysis demonstrated 152 cells/mm3 of ascitic white blood cell count and 30 cells/mm3 of polymorphonuclear cell count 10 hours later after his arrival of emergency department. Arterial blood gas analysis demonstrated a severe metabolic acidosis (pH: 7.38, pCO2: 20.4 mmHg, pO2: 91.8 mmHg; base deficit: 11.2 mmol/L), which was indicative of septic shock.
Oxacillin treatment under the impression of cellulitis was administered 2 hours after his arrival; two sets of blood cultures were obtained. Rapid fluid resuscitation was performed and immediately developed by tracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit. Although there was no significant change of ankle wounds, antibiotic regimen with a combination of ceftriaxone and clindamycin was adjusted due to persistent hypotension unresponsive to fluid resuscitation and high dose vasopressor use and clinical suspicion of Vibrio vulnificus related necrotizing fasciitis.
One episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding with manifestations of fresh blood in the nasogastric tube occurred on Day 2. Blood transfusion with 2 units of packed red blood cells was given. Despite intensive support efforts, the patient died on Day 3 after the sudden change. And after that, his blood and ascites cultures were positive for A. hydrophila.

What is the patient's CHA2DS2-VASc Score?

A 60-year-old gentleman is seen for a follow-up in the clinic. He is a known patient with a significantly compromised pulmonary function due to long-term COPD. Despite being on bronchodilators and inhalational steroids, he has frequent bouts of wheezing. Significant in his medical history is the onset of multiple transient ischemic attacks, however, no residual neurological deficits are appreciated. His vascular history is complicated by peripheral arterial disease, for which he is on medication and advised regular foot care. He has no history of heart failure and myocardial infarction. He is a known patient of diabetes, but lately, his control has been challenging due to nephropathy, indicated by increasing proteinuria and declining glomerular filtration rate. A recent peptic ulcer diagnosis was made during his endoscopy, for which PPI and treatment for 'H. pylori' were prescribed. He manifests symptoms of liver dysfunction with ongoing investigations pointing towards chronic liver disease of moderate severity. Thus far, he has no issues with memory or cognitive function. He denies any HIV exposure, moreover, his clinical history doesn't suggest any solid tumor, lymphoma, leukemia, and connective tissue ailments. Continuation of current treatment and addressing the need for diabetes management and gastroprotection were underlined during his visit. He was also advised lifestyle modifications, regular medical reviews, and tests to monitor progression or regression of his myriad health conditions.

What is the patient's Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI)?

Calculate Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age: <50 years = 0 points, 50-59 years = +1 point, 60-69 years = +2 points, 70-79 years = +3 points, ≥80 years = +4 points
    Myocardial infarction (history of definite or probable MI with EKG changes and/or enzyme changes): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Congestive heart failure (CHF) (exertional or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, responsive to digitalis, diuretics, or afterload reducing agents): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Peripheral vascular disease (intermittent claudication, past bypass for chronic arterial insufficiency, history of gangrene or acute arterial insufficiency, untreated thoracic or abdominal aneurysm ≥6 cm): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Cerebrovascular accident (CVA) or transient ischemic attack (TIA) (history with minor or no residuals): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Dementia (chronic cognitive deficit): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Connective tissue disease: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Peptic ulcer disease (any history of treatment for ulcer disease or ulcer bleeding): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Liver disease: None = 0 points, Mild = +1 point, Moderate to severe = +3 points
    Diabetes mellitus: None or diet-controlled = 0 points, Uncomplicated = +1 point, End-organ damage = +2 points
    Hemiplegia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD): No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Solid tumor: None = 0 points, Localized = +2 points, Metastatic = +6 points
    Leukemia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Lymphoma: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    AIDS: No = 0 points, Yes = +6 points

A 64-year-old woman presented to her general practitioner (GP) with a three-year history of a right frontal skull swelling. Over the past year this swelling had increased in size. The patient was referred to the neurosurgery clinic where examination revealed a sessile non-tender mass (approximately 4.3 x 1.6 cm). The overlying skin was intact with normal hair growth. There was no headache and there were no focal neurological signs or symptoms.
The initial skull X-ray was suggestive of an osteoma. Bone scintigraphy was normal. A CT scan of the head showed a sclerotic thickened area of the right frontal bone with no significant mass effect on the underlying cerebrum (). No brain or meningeal enhancement was noted on the scans. The findings were suggestive of an osteoma, with fibrous dysplasia as another possibility. Review of the scans by a second radiologist confirmed an area of sclerosis and non-destructive expansion of the right frontal bone. However, this was thought to represent an intraosseous meningioma.
The patient was treated surgically and underwent a small skin incision overlying the lesion. The latter was chiselled off and sent for pathological examination in order to obtain a tissue diagnosis. The contour of the skull was restored.
Histologically the sample contained fragments of mature bone, whereby some of the bone marrow spaces were replaced by a spindle cell tumour forming lobules and whorls (). It was composed of cells with oval nuclei, some nuclear pseudoinclusions, eosiniophilic cytoplasm and indistinct cytoplasmic borders. Mitotic figures were not present. The features were consistent with an intraosseous meningioma of meningothelial subtype (WHO Grade I).
The patient was subsequently readmitted and underwent a total excision of the tumour and cranioplasty. The involved right frontal bone was excised and replaced with a titanium mesh.

What is the patient's Wells' criteria score for Deep Vein Thrombosis?

Calculate Wells' Criteria for DVT by summing the results of the following rules:
    Active cancer (treatment or palliation within 6 months): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Bedridden recently >3 days or major surgery within 12 weeks: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Calf swelling >3 cm compared to the other leg (measured 10 cm below tibial tuberosity): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Collateral (nonvaricose) superficial veins present: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Entire leg swollen: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Localized tenderness along the deep venous system: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pitting edema, confined to symptomatic leg: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Paralysis, paresis, or recent plaster immobilization of the lower extremity: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Previously documented DVT: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Alternative diagnosis to DVT as likely or more likely: No = 0 points, Yes = -2 points

A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of body aches and sore throat for 1 week. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives with his parents; they recently adopted a cat from an animal shelter. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The pharynx is red and swollen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11,500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 48%
Band forms 2%
Basophils 0.5%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 45%
Monocytes 3.5%
When the patient's serum is added to a sample of horse erythrocytes, the cells aggregate together.

What is the patient's FeverPAIN score?

A 70-year-old woman came in today for an evaluation of her recent episodes of black, tarry stools. Initially, she showed a rested heart rate at 86 beats per minute, and her blood pressure was plateaued at 115 mmHg systolic. When asked, she denied any recent episodes of fainting but confirmed ongoing management for her hypertension. Results from the lab show a slightly elevated Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) level at 25 mg/dL while her hemoglobin readings are within normal limits at 13 g/dL. The patient takes calcium and Vitamin D supplements to manage her osteoporosis, in addition to a low-salt diet for her hypertension.

What is the patient's Glasgow-Blatchford Bleeding score?

Calculate Glasgow-Blatchford Bleeding Score (GBS) by summing the results of the following rules:
    Hemoglobin level (g/dL): Enter value (norm: 12-17 g/dL)
    BUN level (mg/dL): Enter value (norm: 8-20 mg/dL)
    Initial systolic blood pressure (mm Hg): Enter value (norm: 100-120 mm Hg)
    Sex: Female = +1 point, Male = 0 points
    Heart rate ≥100: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Melena present: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Recent syncope: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Hepatic disease history: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Cardiac failure present: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points

A 64-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for her pre-operative evaluation for high-risk orthopedic surgery for revision hip replacement. Her medical history is significant for a cerebrovascular accident two years ago, with no residual deficits. No known history of congestive heart failure or ischemic heart disease is documented. Her vitals are stable, including a heart rate of 78 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg. The physical examination is unremarkable except for limited mobility due to hip pain. Her respiratory system was clear on auscultation, no edema or jugular vein distention was noticed, and heart sounds were noted to be normal. Laboratory investigations show her creatinine level is 130 µmol/L. Further cardiology and nephrology evaluations and consultations have been planned as part of the pre-surgical risk assessment and management. The patient is also reminded of the need for strict adherence to medication and regular post-operative follow-ups.

A 32-year-old man presents with a fever that has persisted for 3 days. He says that the fever was initially low at around 37.8°C (100.0°F), but, for the past 2 days, it has been around 38.9°C (102.0°F), regardless of his attempts to bring it down. He has also noticed some bumps on his neck. On further questioning, he mentions that he was recently out rabbit hunting with his friends. He is prescribed an antibiotic and requested to follow-up in 2 weeks. On follow-up, the patient seems better, however, he says he now has a slight hearing difficulty.

Calculate Centor Score (Modified/McIsaac) for Strep Pharyngitis by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age: 3-14 years = +1 point, 15-44 years = 0 points, ≥45 years = -1 point
    Exudate or swelling on tonsils: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Tender/swollen anterior cervical lymph nodes: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Temperature >38°C (100.4°F): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Cough: Cough present = 0 points, Cough absent = +1 point

A 60-year-old male with a history of liver failure and immunocompromise presents to the emergency department with acute symptoms of lethargy and decreased appetite. Physical examination reveals tachycardia to 95 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, blood pressure registering at 135/75 mm Hg and a baseline temperature of 37.2°C. Neurological assessment demonstrates mild confusion, corresponding to a Glasgow Coma Score of 14. Blood tests reveal elevated creatinine levels at 3.8 mg/dL. Metabolic panel showed sodium at 138 and potassium at 4.5 mEq/L. The white blood cell count was 12,000 per µL, triggering concern for a possible infection. Hematocrit was just within normal range at 43 %. The patient had an arterial blood gas pH of 7.32 and a A-a-gradient of 364, with a supplementary FiO₂ of 55 %. This patient's acute renal failure symptomatology, alongside the history of severe organ failure and immunocompromised, mandate rigorous monitoring and urgent medical intervention.

What is the patient's APACHE II score?

Calculate APACHE II Score by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age, years: ≤44 = 0 points, 45-54 = +2 points, 55-64 = +3 points, 65-74 = +5 points, ≥75 = +6 points
    History of severe organ insufficiency or immunocompromised: Yes, nonoperative or emergency postoperative patient = +5 points, Yes, elective postoperative patient = +2 points, No = 0 points
    History of severe organ insufficiency or immunocompromised: Yes, nonoperative or emergency postoperative patient = +5 points, Yes, elective postoperative patient = +2 points, No = 0 points
    Rectal temperature, °C: ≥41 = +4 points, 39 to <41 = +3 points, 38.5 to <39 = +1 point, 36 to <38.5 = 0 points, 34 to <36 = +1 point, 32 to <34 = +2 points, 30 to <32 = +3 points, <30 = +4 points
    Mean arterial pressure, mmHg: ≥160 = +4 points, 130-159 = +3 points, 110-129 = +2 points, 70-109 = 0 points, 50-69 = +2 points, 40-49 = +3 points, <40 = +4 points
    Heart rate, beats per minute: ≥180 = +4 points, 140 to <180 = +3 points, 110 to <140 = +2 points, 70 to <110 = 0 points, 55 to <70 = +2 points, 40 to <55 = +3 points, <40 = +4 points
    Respiratory rate, breaths per minute: ≥50 = +4 points, 35 to <50 = +3 points, 25 to <35 = +1 point, 12 to <25 = 0 points, 10 to <12 = +1 point, 6 to <10 = +2 points, <6 = +4 points
    Oxygenation (use PaO2 if FiO2 <50%, otherwise use Aa gradient): Aa gradient >349 = +4 points, Aa gradient 350-349 = +3 points, Aa gradient 200-349 = +2 points, Aa gradient <200 (if FiO2 over 45%) or PaO2 <70 (if FiO2 less than 50%) = +1 point, PaO2 61-70 = +1 point, PaO2 55-60 = +3 points, PaO2 <55 = +4 points
    Arterial pH: ≥7.7 = +4 points, 7.60 to <7.70 = +3 points, 7.50 to <7.60 = +1 point, 7.33 to <7.50 = 0 points, 7.25 to <7.33 = +2 points, 7.15 to <7.25 = +3 points, <7.15 = +4 points
    Serum sodium, mmol/L: ≥180 = +4 points, 160 to <180 = +3 points, 155 to <160 = +2 points, 150 to <155 = +1 point, 130 to <150 = 0 points, 120 to <130 = +2 points, 111 to <120 = +3 points, <111 = +4 points
    Serum potassium, mmol/L: ≥7.0 = +4 points, 6.0 to <7.0 = +3 points, 5.5 to <6.0 = +1 point, 3.5 to <5.5 = 0 points, 3.0 to <3.5 = +1 point, 2.5 to <3.0 = +2 points, <2.5 = +4 points
    Serum creatinine, mg/100 mL: ≥3.5 and ACUTE renal failure = +8 points, 2.0 to <3.5 and ACUTE renal failure = +6 points, ≥3.5 and CHRONIC renal failure = +4 points, 1.5 to <2.0 and ACUTE renal failure = +4 points, 2.0 to <3.5 and CHRONIC renal failure = +3 points, 1.5 to <2.0 and CHRONIC renal failure = +2 points, 0.6 to <1.5 = 0 points, <0.6 = +2 points
    Hematocrit, %: ≥60 = +4 points, 50 to <60 = +2 points, 46 to <50 = +1 point, 30 to <46 = 0 points, 20 to <30 = +2 points, <20 = +4 points
    White blood count, total/cubic mm in 10^3: ≥40 = +4 points, 20 to <40 = +2 points, 15 to <20 = +1 point, 3 to <15 = 0 points, 1 to <3 = +2 points, <1 = +4 points
    Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 1-15 points (use 15 - [GCS Score])

A 75-year-old female was admitted to our ICU with respiratory distress and increased confusion. This patient’s Glasgow Coma Score has been observed at 12, suggestive of a minor to moderate cognitive impairment. She did not require mechanical ventilation; instead, her oxygen requirement was manageable at 55 % FiO₂ resulting in a measured partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) of 75 mm Hg. Hemodynamically, she has been stable throughout the day with a systolic and diastolic blood pressure documented as 115 and 80 mm Hg, respectively. She was given multiple vasopressor treatment regimens which included DOPamine running at 3.2 mcg/kg/min, norEPINEPHrine at 0.05 mcg/kg/min, DOBUTamine at 3 mcg/kg/min, and EPINEPHrine being administered as 0.03 mcg/kg/min. Lab results revealed elevated bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dL and increased creatinine levels of 1.8 mg/dL, offering insights into potential liver and renal impairments. The platelet count was within a normal range as 175,000/µL. She was maintaining a good urine output, recorded at 920 mL/day. This case calls for a meticulous and steady monitoring of her vitals and organ function while in an ICU setup.

What is the patient's Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score?

Calculate Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score by summing the results of the following rules:
    PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio (mm Hg): ≥400 = 0 points, 300-399 = +1 point, 200-299 = +2 points, 100-199 (with respiratory support) = +3 points, <100 (with respiratory support) = +4 points
    Platelets (×10³/µL): ≥150 = 0 points, 100-149 = +1 point, 50-99 = +2 points, 20-49 = +3 points, <20 = +4 points
    Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 15 = 0 points, 13-14 = +1 point, 10-12 = +2 points, 6-9 = +3 points, <6 = +4 points
    Bilirubin (mg/dL): <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-5.9 = +2 points, 6.0-11.9 = +3 points, ≥12.0 = +4 points
    Mean arterial pressure (MAP) or administration of vasopressors: No hypotension = 0 points, MAP <70 mmHg = +1 point, Dopamine ≤5 or Dobutamine (any dose) = +2 points, Dopamine >5 or Epinephrine ≤0.1 or norepinephrine ≤0.1 = +3 points, Dopamine >15 or Epinephrine >0.1 or norepinephrine >0.1 = +4 points
    Creatinine (mg/dL) or urine output: <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-3.4 = +2 points, 3.5-4.9 or urine output <500 mL/day = +3 points, ≥5.0 or urine output <200 mL/day = +4 points

A 77-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, stroke, and prostate cancer presented to the emergency department for accidental ingestion with nausea and vomiting. Approximately 90 minutes prior to arrival, the patient had gone to the refrigerator for water and had mistaken a bottle of 35% hydrogen peroxide for water, subsequently ingesting approximately 150 milliliters (mL). The patient immediately felt a burning sensation in his mouth and throat, followed by nausea and vomiting. He reportedly vomited several times, mostly dry heaving, but at one point had a small amount of blood in the vomitus. He otherwise denied any other complaints.
The patient was in no acute distress upon arrival. His blood pressure was elevated at 157/84 millimeters of mercury, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, pulse 65 beats per minute, and arterial oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. Complete physical examination was negative for posterior oropharyngeal erythema, abdominal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. Laboratory results were significant for an elevated leukocyte count of 18.9 × 103 thousand per millimeters cubed (K/mm3) (reference range: 4.5–11.0 K/mm3), hemoglobin of 16.4 grams per deciliter (g/dL) (12.0–16.0 g/dL), creatinine of 1.7 milligrams (mg)/dL (0.5–1.4 mg/dL), and lipase of 844 U/L (73–393 U/L). Initial imaging via computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast revealed gastric pneumatosis extending into the distal esophagus with extensive portal venous air, diverticulosis, multiple left renal cysts, and a 5.8-centimeter (cm) adrenal myolipoma ().
Given the patient’s presenting symptoms combined with the CT findings of gastric pneumatosis, the poison center and gastroenterology were consulted. The patient was admitted for observation with plans for an endoscopy; however, upon surgical consultation, he was emergently transferred to a tertiary care hospital due to concerns for a potential perforation and necrosis of the gastric body and distal esophagus, which may have necessitated a total gastrectomy as well as distal esophagectomy. The patient had been placed on a nothing-by-mouth restriction on admission and was hemodynamically stable on intravenous (IV) fluids, pantoprazole IV drip, and piperacillin-tazobactam at time of transfer.
Upon arrival at the tertiary center, the patient reported overall improvement of his abdominal pain and sore mouth. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy performed there confirmed moderate to severe distal esophagitis and severe pangastritis but no evidence of necrosis, linear ulcerations along the lesser curvature, or mild bulbar duodenitis. Gastric biopsy later demonstrated fundic type gastric mucosa with acute inflammation and epithelial erosion. Following his endoscopy, the patient tolerated clear liquids and had his diet advanced to surgical soft. He remained pain-free and was deemed stable for discharge on the third day with recommendations for a repeat endoscopy in two to three months.

Calculate FeverPAIN Score for Strep Pharyngitis by summing the results of the following rules:
    Fever in past 24 hours: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Absence of cough or coryza: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Symptom onset ≤3 days: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Purulent tonsils: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Severe tonsil inflammation: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 60-year-old male with a history of thyroid surgery was rushed to the emergency department after collapsing at home. The patient's wife reported he complained of difficulty breathing. Emergency airway was required and a tracheostomy was performed by EMS on site. On physical examination, his hemisphere functions such as sensation, power, tone, and deep tendon reflexes are intact on both sides and he is able to obey commands to grip and release his hand. He opens his eyes when pinched but does not attempt to verbalize due to the tracheostomy. Initial vital signs are; a heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure 140/85 mmHg, respiratory rate 19 breaths per minute, and O2 saturation 93 % on room air. Blood work including complete blood count, coagulation panel, comprehensive metabolic panel, and arterial blood gas is collected. ENT is consulted for a tracheostomy review and the patient is admitted to ICU for further care.

What is the patient's Glasgow Coma Score?

Calculate Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) by summing the results of the following rules:
    Best Eye Response: Spontaneously = +4 points, To verbal command = +3 points, To pain = +2 points, No eye opening = +1 point
    Best Verbal Response: Oriented = +5 points, Confused = +4 points, Inappropriate words = +3 points, Incomprehensible sounds = +2 points, No verbal response = +1 point
    Best Motor Response: Obeys commands = +6 points, Localizes pain = +5 points, Withdrawal from pain = +4 points, Flexion to pain = +3 points, Extension to pain = +2 points, No motor response = +1 point

A 68-year-old gentleman presents for a pre-operative evaluation for his upcoming direct inguinal hernia repair. His medical background includes a diagnosis of ischemic heart disease, and he had a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction five years ago. In addition to this, he had a transient ischemic attack two years ago but has shown satisfactory recovery since then. His type 2 diabetes is managed with metformin. On examination, his vitals are within a satisfactory range. Lab investigations display a slightly elevated creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, which will be monitored closely. Given his previous cardiological events, the patient is referred to cardiology to ensure optimal management of his ischemic heart disease before surgery.

What is the patient's Cardiac Risk Index based on the revised Cardiac Risk Index for pre-operative risk rule?

A 68-year-old gentleman presents for a pre-operative evaluation for his upcoming direct inguinal hernia repair. His medical background includes a diagnosis of ischemic heart disease, and he had a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction five years ago. In addition to this, he had a transient ischemic attack two years ago but has shown satisfactory recovery since then. His type 2 diabetes is managed with metformin. On examination, his vitals are within a satisfactory range. Lab investigations display a slightly elevated creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, which will be monitored closely. Given his previous cardiological events, the patient is referred to cardiology to ensure optimal management of his ischemic heart disease before surgery.

Calculate Revised Cardiac Risk Index for Pre-Operative Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Elevated-risk surgery (intraperitoneal, intrathoracic, or suprainguinal vascular): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of ischemic heart disease (history of myocardial infarction, positive exercise test, current chest pain due to myocardial ischemia, use of nitrate therapy, or ECG with pathological Q waves): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of congestive heart failure (pulmonary edema, bilateral rales or S3 gallop, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest x-ray showing pulmonary vascular redistribution): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of cerebrovascular disease (prior transient ischemic attack or stroke): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative treatment with insulin: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative creatinine >2 mg/dL (176.8 μmol/L): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 42-year-old African American woman with a history of hypertension, morbid obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea presented to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of left-sided abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. At presentation, her medications included hydrochlorothiazide, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and lisinopril. The patient is married, has three children, and has never smoked, consumed alcohol, or used illicit drugs.
The patient had travelled to Ghana for 5 days, 1 month prior to presentation. She denies any symptoms during or since her trip until her current symptoms started. She was prescribed lisinopril for hypertension, and her first dose of lisinopril 5 mg was 12 h before the onset of her symptoms. She had never taken an ACE inhibitor (ACEi) or angiotensin II receptor antagonist (ARB) before.
On presentation, she had crampy abdominal pain that radiated to the left side of her abdomen. Her pain was constant and increasing but did wax and wane in severity. She also had persistent nausea with one bout of emesis. She had one nonbloody bowel movement of normal caliber within 24 h of presenting and denied any recent diarrhea, constipation, or recent sick contacts.
Vitals at presentation included a blood pressure of 187/122, pulse of 81, temperature of 36.7°C, respirations of 20, and an O2 saturation of 100% on room air. Physical examination showed a patient that appeared uncomfortable and at times sitting up and writhing in bed with her eyes closed. Her abdomen was tender to palpation in the left epigastric area and left mid-abdomen, with mild left suprapubic tenderness. She also had hyperactive bowel sounds but no rebound tenderness or significant guarding.
In the emergency department, the patient received intravenous fluids, as well as pain and nausea medications. The laboratories showed an unremarkable CBC. Her C1 esterase inhibitor functional assay was within normal limits along with a normal C4 concentration making type I and type II hereditary angioedema unlikely. Stool studies were negative for infectious diseases. CT of the abdomen showed segmented target-like enhancement of a dilated loop of ileum with relatively high attenuation ascites (Figs and ). The initial differential included inflammatory bowel disease, infectious enteritis, vasculitis intramural hemorrhage, and lymphoma.
Given her admission clinical and radiographic findings, drug-induced visceral angioedema due to ACEi was suspected. Lisinopril was discontinued and the patient's abdominal symptoms resolved completely in 48 h. The patient was discharged to home on 5 mg of amlodipine for blood pressure control and instructed to follow-up with her primary care provider. On follow-up 2 and 8 weeks later, her symptoms had not returned.

Calculate PERC Rule for Pulmonary Embolism by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age ≥50: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Heart Rate (HR) ≥100: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    O₂ saturation on room air <95%: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Unilateral leg swelling: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Hemoptysis: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

The patient in question is a 68-year-old individual, known to have previously experienced severe liver failure managed with medications. Currently, the individual presented to the outpatient clinic, complaining of increased fatigue. On physical examination, the patient exhibited a body temperature of 37.6 degrees celsisus with a heart rate of 89 beats per minute. Blood pressure was measured at 110/72 mm Hg and respiratory rate was recorded as 16 breaths per minute. Neurologic evaluation yielded a perfect Glasgow Coma Score of 15. The laboratory results suggested elevated creatinine at 1.9 mg/dL, combined with a white blood cell count of 7000/µL. The sodium level is towards the lower end of normal at 136 mEq/L with potassium within the normal range, documented at 4.2 mEq/L. The patient's arterial blood gas showed a typical pH of 7.4 with a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) being 78 mm Hg on 45 % FiO₂. The hematocrit level was mildly reduced to 38 %. Given the patient's history of severe organ failure, the current clinical context and the elevated creatinine levels necessitate further evaluation and careful monitoring.

The patient was a 76-year-old man with a history of mild dysphasia. He had a prior history of cerebral infarctions (x3) at the age of 66, 74 and 75 years, with a first instance of swallowing difficulties after the third stroke. At that time, dysphasia rehabilitation was initiated within 3 days of the stroke, and he recovered the ability to eat a regular meal within 2 weeks. In January 2018, 1-year after his last stroke, he underwent surgery for spinal stenosis, followed by a 10-day period of bedrest. His physical activity level subsequently declined due to back pain, and he lost 10 kg within the 10 months after surgery. Swallowing difficulties re-emerged in September 2018, with the patient only able to tolerate soft meals. His dysphasia worsened, with an increase in sputum and development of a chronic cough.
His medical history included cerebral infarctions (x3), diabetes mellitus, spinal stenosis, and hypertension. His height was 168.8 cm, with a body weight of 56.5 kg. He had a right hemiplegia, with the following functional measures: grip strength, 25 kg; gait speed, 0.7 m/s, assessed using the 5-m walk test; and skeletal mass index, 6.6 kg/m2. His score of 5 points on the Mini Nutritional Assessment Short Form was indicative of malnourishment. Absence of another cerebral infarct was confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging. Video-endoscopic swallowing assessment showed saliva pooling in the pharynx, widening of the pharyngeal space, vallecular and pyriform sinus residue, and aspiration (A). Video-fluorography revealed a decrease in the forward movement of the larynx, a widened pharyngeal space, weakened pharyngeal constriction, vallecular and pyriform sinus residue, and aspiration (A–C). Functional swallowing scores were as follows: Hyodo score, 9; Fujishima grade, 6; FILS, 8; and dysphasia severity scale, 4. A probable diagnosis of sarcopenic dysphagia was made, based on the criteria defined by Mori et al. [] Clinical management included swallowing training, a high-protein diet, and nutritional guidance. The patient declined additional rehabilitation, due to his previous experience post-stroke. Therefore, we presented laryngeal suspension as a possible alternative treatment, which was performed in December 2018.
Laryngeal suspension was performed via a minimally invasive thyromadibulopexy, using two skin incisions: one (2-cm) incision at the level of the mandible and the other (3-cm) between the hyoid bone and the superior border of the thyroid cartilage (A). Identified the white line, divided aside the anterior cervical muscles, and exposed the thyroid cartilage. Also the mandible was exposed. Two holes in the mandibular and six holes in the thyroid cartilage was made by using drill. The thyroid cartilage was fixed to the mandible using No. 2 nylon. No. 2 nylon thread was passed through the Gore-tex sheet cut to the size of thyroid cartilage. And it was passed through the thyroid cartilage, subcutaneous tunnel on the hyoid bone, mandible, subcutaneous tunnel on the hyoid bone, and tied to the other side of the nylon. As the two holes of the middle of the thyroid cartilage, two No. 2 nylons was crossed to fix the thyroid cartilage and mandible. The larynx was suspended about one vertebral body by totally using five No. 2 nylons (B), confirmed by X-ray fluoroscopy. A 1-cm incision was performed for tracheotomy, and cuffed tracheal cannula was inserted for airway management.
Maintaining some neck flexion for a period of 1-week was conducted. Nutritional support was initiated via gastrostomy tube feeding. The cuffed tracheal cannula was changed to an uncuffed cannula on postoperative day (POD) 1. The wound was stable and there was no pain. Swallowing was initiated using jelly and cold tea, with the patient in a flat lateral position. The tracheal cannula was removed on POD 4. Video-fluorography revealed contrast agent residue in the vallecular but with a decrease in residue in the pyriform sinus compared to pre-operative measures, with no evidence of aspiration on POD 6 (A–C). Anterosuperior movement of the larynx was improved, reaching one vertebral level higher than before surgery. The swallowing reflex was maintained, with sufficient opening of the esophageal orifice, avoiding the need for mandibular protrusion to swallow. Swallowing using modified food was initiated in a sitting position on POD 6 and the gastrostomy tube was removed on POD 7. Video-endoscopic examination confirmed his ability to eat a rice cracker and noodles without aspiration and no evidence of pharyngeal residue on POD 11 (B). The patient was able to eat soft meals on POD 14, and a regular meal on POD 18, and was discharged on POD 21. The patient gained 2 kg in the 2 months after surgery, with improvement in functional scores: Hyodo score, 5; Fujishima grade, 8; FILS, 8; and dysphasia severity scale, 6. There was no exacerbation of the condition over a 10-month period after surgery, and the patient has a normal diet and is able to travel. Neck movement restriction was not severe.

What is the patient's CHA2DS2-VASc Score?

Calculate CHA2DS2-VASc Score for Atrial Fibrillation Stroke Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age: < 65 years = 0 points, 65-74 years = +1 point, ≥ 75 years = +2 points
    Sex: Female = +1 point, Male = 0 points
    Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Hypertension history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Stroke, Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA), or Thromboembolism history: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Vascular disease history (previous myocardial infarction, peripheral artery disease, or aortic plaque): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Diabetes history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 52-year-old patient with a known medical history characterized by several organ failures managed with medications presented to the hospital with general malaise and signs of confusion. On examination, the patient had a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute and the blood pressure measurement displayed 120/70 mm Hg. The respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, with oxygen saturation stably maintained on 60 % FiO₂. Basal temperature was found to be normal, at 37°C. Initial neurological evaluation revealed a slightly lowered level of consciousness, with a Glasgow Coma Score of 12. Laboratory workup showed a normal creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL, indicating no recent onset of renal impairment. Complete blood count displayed a white blood cell count of 7000 per microliter, within the reference ranges. Routine electrolyte panel demonstrated sodium and potassium concentrations at 137 and 4.8 mEq/L, respectively. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.35 with a A-a-gradient of 375. Hematocrit level was observed at a standard 45 %. Owing to the patient's historical pattern of severe organ failure and present immunocompromised state, continued vigilance and monitoring are of paramount importance for any signs of potential complications.

What is the patient's APACHE II score?

A 63-year-old man was admitted to the ICU following a sudden drop in consciousness level. Currently, his Glasgow Coma Score is listed as 12. Despite his conditioned state, his blood pressure remains stable with systolic and diastolic pressures recorded at 118 and 74 mm Hg respectively. The patient is mechanically ventilated, and oxygen therapy reveals a FiO₂ of 52 % which allows him to maintain a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) at 76 mm Hg. Multiple vasopressors are administered to support hemodynamic stability, these include DOPamine and DOBUTamine infusions running at 4.2 mcg/kg/min and 3.8 mcg/kg/min respectively, and norEPINEPHrine along with EPINEPHrine controlled at the rate of 0.03 mcg/kg/min and 0.02 mcg/kg/min respectively. Laboratory analysis rendered a serum creatinine level of 140 µmol/L and a total bilirubin level scaled at 2.2 mg/dL, specs that suggest mild renal impairment along with a probable hepatic dysfunction. The reported platelet count suggested normalcy at 165,000/µL of blood. A daily urine output is listed close to 880 mL/day, recording a satisfactory level of fluid balance. Careful monitoring and management are needed to uphold his potential recovery.

What is the patient's Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score?

Calculate Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score by summing the results of the following rules:
    PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio (mm Hg): ≥400 = 0 points, 300-399 = +1 point, 200-299 = +2 points, 100-199 (with respiratory support) = +3 points, <100 (with respiratory support) = +4 points
    Platelets (×10³/µL): ≥150 = 0 points, 100-149 = +1 point, 50-99 = +2 points, 20-49 = +3 points, <20 = +4 points
    Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 15 = 0 points, 13-14 = +1 point, 10-12 = +2 points, 6-9 = +3 points, <6 = +4 points
    Bilirubin (mg/dL): <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-5.9 = +2 points, 6.0-11.9 = +3 points, ≥12.0 = +4 points
    Mean arterial pressure (MAP) or administration of vasopressors: No hypotension = 0 points, MAP <70 mmHg = +1 point, Dopamine ≤5 or Dobutamine (any dose) = +2 points, Dopamine >5 or Epinephrine ≤0.1 or norepinephrine ≤0.1 = +3 points, Dopamine >15 or Epinephrine >0.1 or norepinephrine >0.1 = +4 points
    Creatinine (mg/dL) or urine output: <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-3.4 = +2 points, 3.5-4.9 or urine output <500 mL/day = +3 points, ≥5.0 or urine output <200 mL/day = +4 points

A 68-year-old male patient arrives for presurgical consultation before planned shoulder arthroscopy. His medical records indicate a history of coronary artery disease and congestive heart failure. He had a bypass surgery 5 years ago due to significant left main coronary artery stenosis. He denies any history of cerebrovascular events, such as stroke or transient ischemic attack. He endorses orthopnea and bilateral lower extremity edema. The patient's heart rate is 83 beats per minute and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. The cardiopulmonary exam shows jugular venous distention, an S3 heart sound, and crackles at both lung bases. His renal function tests return with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. His echocardiogram suggests reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Cardiac optimization is recommended prior to surgery with an increased dose of his diuretic. The patient is also reminded of the importance of a low-salt diet to manage his heart failure.

What is the patient's Cardiac Risk Index based on the revised Cardiac Risk Index for pre-operative risk rule?

His echocardiogram suggests reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Cardiac optimization is recommended prior to surgery with an increased dose of his diuretic. The patient is also reminded of the importance of a low-salt diet to manage his heart failure.

Calculate Revised Cardiac Risk Index for Pre-Operative Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Elevated-risk surgery (intraperitoneal, intrathoracic, or suprainguinal vascular): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of ischemic heart disease (history of myocardial infarction, positive exercise test, current chest pain due to myocardial ischemia, use of nitrate therapy, or ECG with pathological Q waves): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of congestive heart failure (pulmonary edema, bilateral rales or S3 gallop, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest x-ray showing pulmonary vascular redistribution): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    History of cerebrovascular disease (prior transient ischemic attack or stroke): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative treatment with insulin: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Pre-operative creatinine >2 mg/dL (176.8 μmol/L): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 55-year-old right-handed male presented to the emergency department after a syncopal episode. He was teaching a karate class when a coworker saw him fall to the ground. He spontaneously regained consciousness after a few seconds but was confused for ∼15–20 min. He had no recollection of the event, and was hemodynamically stable and neurologically intact. He denied illicit drug use. Vitals, physical examination and laboratory studies were within normal limits. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with normal PR and QT intervals and no ST-T wave changes. He was on no AV blocking agents. Head CT showed no intracranial bleed or mass lesion.
He had a history of five similar episodes in the past. During the last episode, he had been noted to have sinus arrest on telemetry and underwent single atrial lead pacemaker placement. The pacemaker was programmed to AAI mode. AV conduction was tested and was normal. Coronary angiogram showed no evidence of coronary artery disease. EEG had been minimally abnormal with left temporal theta slowing, suggestive of an area of neurophysiologic dysfunction, but no epileptiform activity was noted. He had no history of febrile seizures, central nervous system infection or cranial trauma.
The patient was admitted for further work up. Continuous EEG monitoring was ordered to evaluate for seizure activity. At ∼7 min and 36 s, the patient started to have recurrent automatisms and became unresponsive, with the EEG showing complex partial seizure activity emanating from the left anterior temporal region with continued post-ictal right temporal delta slowing. The seizure lasted ∼1 min. The simultaneous ECG lead demonstrated heart rate slowing toward the end of the seizure episode, with the rhythm changing from sinus to atrially paced at 60 beats min−1 with 1:1 conduction, to atrially paced with 2:1 AV block, followed by complete heart block for 4 s, followed by resumption of the baseline atrially paced rhythm with 1:1 conduction (Fig. ).
Cardiac electrophysiology recommended treating the seizure episodes before considering upgrade of the pacemaker to a dual-chamber device. The patient was started and subsequently discharged on levetiracetam. More than 15 months later, he has had no seizures or syncopal events.

What is the patient's CHA2DS2-VASc Score?

A 62-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension has been hospitalized for severe fatigue and weight loss. Despite manifesting a clear and oriented mental status, Glasgow Coma Score of 15, he displays other concerning symptoms. Neurological examination showed no abnormalities; however, lab workup revealed elevated bilirubin levels of 7.43 mg/dL. As well, impaired renal function was evident from a creatinine level of 2.56 mg/dL. Intravenous vasopressors, specifically EPINEPHrine of 0.33 mcg/kg/min and DOPamine of 9.1 mcg/kg/min, were administered to maintain a stable circulatory status, the patient currently is not presenting signs of hypotension, furthermore, the patient is not currently on mechanical ventilation or continuous positive airway pressure, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂) at 53 % and a measured partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) of 87 mm Hg. Thrombocytopenia was noted with a platelet count of 75,300/µL. He has not undergone continuous veno-venous hemodialysis in the past week. Urine output has not been recoreded.

What is the patient's Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score?

As well, impaired renal function was evident from a creatinine level of 2.56 mg/dL. Intravenous vasopressors, specifically EPINEPHrine of 0.33 mcg/kg/min and DOPamine of 9.1 mcg/kg/min, were administered to maintain a stable circulatory status, the patient currently is not presenting signs of hypotension, furthermore, the patient is not currently on mechanical ventilation or continuous positive airway pressure, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂) at 53 % and a measured partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) of 87 mm Hg. Thrombocytopenia was noted with a platelet count of 75,300/µL. He has not undergone continuous veno-venous hemodialysis in the past week. Urine output has not been recoreded.

Calculate Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score by summing the results of the following rules:
    PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio (mm Hg): ≥400 = 0 points, 300-399 = +1 point, 200-299 = +2 points, 100-199 (with respiratory support) = +3 points, <100 (with respiratory support) = +4 points
    Platelets (×10³/µL): ≥150 = 0 points, 100-149 = +1 point, 50-99 = +2 points, 20-49 = +3 points, <20 = +4 points
    Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 15 = 0 points, 13-14 = +1 point, 10-12 = +2 points, 6-9 = +3 points, <6 = +4 points
    Bilirubin (mg/dL): <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-5.9 = +2 points, 6.0-11.9 = +3 points, ≥12.0 = +4 points
    Mean arterial pressure (MAP) or administration of vasopressors: No hypotension = 0 points, MAP <70 mmHg = +1 point, Dopamine ≤5 or Dobutamine (any dose) = +2 points, Dopamine >5 or Epinephrine ≤0.1 or norepinephrine ≤0.1 = +3 points, Dopamine >15 or Epinephrine >0.1 or norepinephrine >0.1 = +4 points
    Creatinine (mg/dL) or urine output: <1.2 = 0 points, 1.2-1.9 = +1 point, 2.0-3.4 = +2 points, 3.5-4.9 or urine output <500 mL/day = +3 points, ≥5.0 or urine output <200 mL/day = +4 points

A 65-year-old female patient with history of Hepatitis B, DM type II, and recently diagnosed cirrhosis visited the clinic for her scheduled visit. A firm liver edge was palpated below the costal margin, but there was no detectable ascites on physical examination. Laboratory evaluation revealed a direct bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL and a total bilirubin of 3.0 mg/dL. INR was 1.3. Her albumin level was 3.4 g/dL, slightly below normal range. Elevated levels for serum alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase were also noted. Her random blood sugar was measured at 155 mg/dL and her BUN/Creatinine ratios were within normal limits. She was encouraged to abstain from alcohol, follow a low salt diet to prevent fluid accumulation, and regular follow-up visits for monitoring were scheduled.

What is the patient's Child-Pugh Score?

Calculate Child-Pugh Score for Cirrhosis Mortality by summing the results of the following rules:
    Bilirubin (Total): <2 mg/dL (<34.2 μmol/L) = +1 point, 2-3 mg/dL (34.2-51.3 μmol/L) = +2 points, >3 mg/dL (>51.3 μmol/L) = +3 points
    Albumin: >3.5 g/dL (>35 g/L) = +1 point, 2.8-3.5 g/dL (28-35 g/L) = +2 points, <2.8 g/dL (<28 g/L) = +3 points
    INR: <1.7 = +1 point, 1.7-2.3 = +2 points, >2.3 = +3 points
    Ascites: Absent = +1 point, Slight = +2 points, Moderate = +3 points
    Encephalopathy: No Encephalopathy = +1 point, Grade 1-2 = +2 points, Grade 3-4 = +3 points

A 90-year-old gentleman presents to the clinic with the following medical history. He has uncontrolled type II diabetes now complicated by chronic kidney disease with a creatinine of 4.0 mg/dL. The patient had lung cancer, which is currently in remission after chemotherapy and radiation. He is now undergoing chemotherapy for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He has suffered transient ischemic attacks in the past but managed to avoid lasting neurological consequences. The patient's labs indicate moderate liver disease without clinical manifestations. He does not have heart failure or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. There are no cognitive changes or memory deficits suggestive of dementia. Upon examination, no signs of hemiplegia are noted. His cardiac history does not demonstrate any myocardial infarction and gastroscopy results are negative for peptic ulcer disease. No record of lymphoma, AIDS, connective tissue disease, or peripheral vascular disease is found in his past medical records.

What is the patient's Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI)?

Calculate Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) by summing the results of the following rules:
    Age: <50 years = 0 points, 50-59 years = +1 point, 60-69 years = +2 points, 70-79 years = +3 points, ≥80 years = +4 points
    Myocardial infarction (history of definite or probable MI with EKG changes and/or enzyme changes): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Congestive heart failure (CHF) (exertional or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, responsive to digitalis, diuretics, or afterload reducing agents): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Peripheral vascular disease (intermittent claudication, past bypass for chronic arterial insufficiency, history of gangrene or acute arterial insufficiency, untreated thoracic or abdominal aneurysm ≥6 cm): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Cerebrovascular accident (CVA) or transient ischemic attack (TIA) (history with minor or no residuals): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Dementia (chronic cognitive deficit): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Connective tissue disease: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Peptic ulcer disease (any history of treatment for ulcer disease or ulcer bleeding): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Liver disease: None = 0 points, Mild = +1 point, Moderate to severe = +3 points
    Diabetes mellitus: None or diet-controlled = 0 points, Uncomplicated = +1 point, End-organ damage = +2 points
    Hemiplegia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD): No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Solid tumor: None = 0 points, Localized = +2 points, Metastatic = +6 points
    Leukemia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    Lymphoma: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
    AIDS: No = 0 points, Yes = +6 points

A 65-year-old gentleman presents to the free clinic. For past medical history, he is known to have experienced a stroke several years ago. Beyond this, he does not have any history of hypertension. He consumes alcohol on a weekly basis, estimating about 10 drinks per week. His treatment plan includes clopidogrel for his stroke. Interestingly, his blood tests have persistently suggested renal disease with evidence of elevated creatinine (baseline ~2.8 mg/dL) and decreased glomerular filtration rate. His INR has remained stable in the consecutive lab tests, ruling out any lability. His medical documentation does not suggest any prior major bleeding instances or known predisposition to bleeding. His health condition undoubtedly makes his case an interesting one for the management team, emphasizing a need for rigorous supervision over his health journey.

What is the patient's HAS-BLED score?

Calculate HAS-BLED Score for Major Bleeding Risk by summing the results of the following rules:
    Hypertension (Uncontrolled, >160 mmHg systolic): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Renal disease (Dialysis, transplant, Cr >2.26 mg/dL or >200 µmol/L): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Liver disease (Cirrhosis or bilirubin >2x normal with AST/ALT/AP >3x normal): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Stroke history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Prior major bleeding or predisposition to bleeding: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Labile INR (Unstable/high INRs, time in therapeutic range <60%): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Age >65: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Medication usage predisposing to bleeding (Aspirin, clopidogrel, NSAIDs): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
    Alcohol use (≥8 drinks/week): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

A 61-year-old male presented to our emergency department complaining of worsening shortness of breath associated with pleuritic chest pain for 3 days. His medical comorbidities included hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, seizure disorder, obstructive sleep apnea, and a history of pulmonary embolism. His only surgery was an inguinal hernia repair in the past. He reported an allergy to angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. He denied alcohol consumption, smoking, or recreational drug use. He had not travelled outside the United States, nor did he encounter any sick contacts. He denied the use of any herbal preparations or over-the-counter medications. Coumadin was the only prescription medication he was taking on a regular basis.
On examination, the patient was a well-built man in respiratory distress. He was tachypneic and hypoxic, saturating at 88% (SpO2) on room air. Blood pressure was 130/80, heart rate 88 bpm, and he was afebrile at 97 °F. On inspection, no icterus, lymphadenopathy, or peripheral edema was noted. On auscultation, his lungs were clear bilaterally, and no heart murmurs were appreciated. His abdomen was soft, non-tender with no hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds were normal.
Initial troponin and pro-brain natriuretic peptide levels were elevated. A computerized tomography with contrast of the chest revealed multiple filling defects within the pulmonary arterial system, indicative of bilateral acute on chronic thromboembolic disease. The patient was started on enoxaparin 120 mg twice a day in addition to his coumadin, as an aim to bridge to a therapeutic international normalized ratio between 2 and 3.
On admission, his liver enzymes were within normal limits as per our institute laboratory values, with an alanine transaminase (ALT) of 28 units/L, aspartate transaminase (AST) of 13 units/L, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) of 95 units/L, albumin of 3.4 g/dL, total bilirubin of 0.4 mg/dL, and conjugated bilirubin of 0.1 mg/dL. They remained as such, up until day 6, when a slight elevation was noted. On day 6, the AST was 72 units/L, ALT was 84 units/L, and ALP was 161 units/L. An R ratio, the initial step of the Roussel Uclaf Causality Assessment Method (RUCAM), was calculated to be 2.64, consistent with a mixed (hepatocellular and cholestatic) pattern of liver injury. At this point, no changes were made to the patient's treatment regimen. On day 7, his liver enzymes peaked with AST of 143 units/L, ALT of 231 units/L, and ALP of 123 units/L as shown in Table . R ratio from these laboratory values was 5.56, consistent with hepatocellular pattern of liver injury.
An ultrasound and computerized tomography of the abdomen was negative for any significant pathology. Echocardiogram of the heart revealed a normal ejection fraction and normal diastolic function. Serologies for hepatitis A, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, Epstein Barr virus, and cytomegalovirus were all negative. Antinuclear antibody screen, anti-mitochondrial antibody, anti-smooth muscle antibody, and anti-liver kidney microsomal antibody were also negative. Serum alpha-1 antitrypsin and serum ceruloplasmin levels were normal.
On day 7 of admission, enoxaparin was discontinued secondary to a therapeutic international normalized ratio. His liver function tests demonstrated a dramatic and steady decline thereafter. He was subsequently discharged on coumadin, and a 2-month follow-up revealed complete normalization of his liver enzymes.
